content.text: The drag force \(D\) on an object of cross-sectional area \(A\), moving with a speed \(v\) through a fluid of density \(\rho\), is given by
where \(C\) is a constant
Show that \(C\) has no unit
On Fig. 1.1, sketch a graph to show the variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the raindrop for the first 1.0s of the motion
Calculate the velocity of the raindrop after falling 1000m
A raindrop falls vertically from rest. Assume that air resistance is negligible
State an equation relating the forces acting on the raindrop when it is falling at terminal velocity

The raindrop has mass \(1.4 \times 10^{- 5} \text{kg}\) and cross-sectional area \(7.1 \times 10^{- 6} \text{m}^2\). The density of the air is \(1.2 \text{kg} \text{m}^{- 3}\) and the initial velocity of the raindrop is zero. The value of \(C\) is 0.60
1. Show that the terminal velocity of the raindrop is about \(7 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\)

2. The raindrop reaches terminal velocity after falling approximately \(10 \text{m}\). On Fig. 1.1, sketch the variation with time \(t\) of velocity \(v\) for the raindrop. The sketch should include the first \(5 \text{s}\) of the motion
In practice, air resistance on raindrops is not negligible because there is a drag force. This drag force is given by the expression in (a)
State Newton's second law
the change in momentum,
the magnitude of the average force

A ball of mass \(65 \mathrm{~g}\) hits a wall with a velocity of \(5.2 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) perpendicular to the wall. The ball rebounds perpendicularly from the wall with a speed of \(3.7 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\). The contact time of the ball with the wall is \(7.5 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}\)
Calculate, for the ball hitting the wall,
For the collision in **(b)** between the ball and the wall, state how the following apply:
1. Newton's third law,
2. the law of conservation of momentum
State, with a reason, whether the collision is elastic or inelastic

polymers:

1. point P,
2. point S

Fig. 4.1 shows an arrangement for producing stationary waves in a tube that is closed at one end
Use Kirchhoff's first law to state a relationship between \(I_{1}, I_{2}\) and \(I_{3}\)
Calculate \(I_{1}\)
Calculate the ratio \(x\) , where

content.blockMath: \[x = \frac{\text{power in metal wire}}{\text{power in series resistors}}.\]

content.text: Calculate the potential difference (p.d.) between the points C and D, as shown in Fig. 5.1. The distance AC is \(40 \text{cm}\) and D is the point between the two series resistors

Fig. 5.1 shows a \(12\mathrm{V}\) power supply with negligible internal resistance connected to a uniform metal wire AB. The wire has length \(1.00\mathrm{m}\) and resistance \(10\Omega\) .Two resistors of resistance \(4.0\Omega\) and \(2.0\Omega\) are connected in series across the wire
Currents \(I_{1}, I_{2}\) and \(I_{3}\) in the circuit are as shown in Fig. 5.1
State Hooke's law

A spring is attached to a support and hangs vertically, as shown in Fig. 6.1. An object M of mass \(0.41 \text{kg}\) is attached to the lower end of the spring. The spring extends until M is at rest at R
The spring constant of the spring is \(25 \text{N} \text{m}^{-1}\). Show that the extension of the spring is about \(0.16 \text{m}\)
state the forces acting on M,
calculate the acceleration of M
The object M in Fig. 6.1 is pulled down a further \(0.060 \text{m}\) to S and is then released. For M, just as it is released,
Describe and explain the energy changes from the time the object M in Fig. 6.1 is released to the time it first returns to R
